path_1.title: French Kiss (1995)
path_1.feeling: Charming enough, but the chase and schmaltz outweigh the wit.

path_1.title: Bottle Rocket (1996)
path_1.feeling: Offbeat crime caper whose low-key humor and friendship beats click with me.

path_1.title: Jungle Book, The (1967)
path_1.feeling: Pleasant, breezy tunes and simple adventure—nice, not vital.

path_1.title: Meet the Deedles (1998)
path_1.feeling: Dopey premise and broad gags wear thin fast.

path_1.title: Good Morning, Vietnam (1987)
path_1.feeling: The irreverence lands even as the drama occasionally turns syrupy.

path_1.title: Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil (1997)
path_1.feeling: Moody and meandering, but the slow-burn mystery kept me engaged.

path_1.title: Roger & Me (1989)
path_1.feeling: Pointed, funny, and bleakly resonant, even if it circles the same points.

path_1.title: Phenomenon (1996)
path_1.feeling: A sweet idea played too saccharine for my taste.

path_1.title: Evil Dead, The (1981)
path_1.feeling: Gonzo cabin-in-the-woods energy and handmade scares win me over despite the splatter.

path_1.title: Angel Heart (1987)
path_1.feeling: Sultry, ominous noir-horror that digs under my skin.

path_1.title: Event Horizon (1997)
path_1.feeling: Creepy concept undercut by clunky sci-fi plotting, but the dread works in stretches.

path_1.title: Vanishing, The (1993)
path_1.feeling: Grim hook, weaker execution

path_1.title: 2010: The Year We Make Contact (1984)
path_1.feeling: Talky, earnest sci-fi that feels small and stodgy.

path_1.title: Airplane! (1980)
path_1.feeling: Rapid-fire absurdity that nails my satire sweet spot from start to finish.

path_1.title: Mrs. Winterbourne (1996)
path_1.feeling: Comfortable melodrama with a soapiness I can only take so far.

path_1.title: Dead Again (1991)
path_1.feeling: A stylish, twisty noir-romance that scratches my mystery itch.

path_1.title: Money Talks (1997)
path_1.feeling: Loud, frantic buddy-crime shtick that mostly grates.

path_1.title: Bob Roberts (1992)
path_1.feeling: Biting political satire with songs-as-speeches that hits the right nerves.

path_1.title: Mumford (1999)
path_1.feeling: Genial small-town quirk that goes down easy if a bit lightweight.

path_1.title: Innerspace (1987)
path_1.feeling: Goofy sci-fi romp with enough charm to keep me smiling.

path_1.title: When Harry Met Sally... (1989)
path_1.feeling: Smart, witty banter and warm chemistry—my kind of rom-com.

path_1.title: Girl 6 (1996)
path_1.feeling: Intriguing premise, uneven execution

path_1.title: Name of the Rose, The (Name der Rose, Der) (1986)
path_1.feeling: Craft-focused peek behind a production—interesting but niche.

path_1.title: Clerks (1994)
path_1.feeling: Rude, rapid-fire chatter and slacker truths I happily groove with.

path_1.title: Mighty Ducks, The (1992)
path_1.feeling: Formulaic but amiable

path_1.title: Goodbye Girl, The (1977)
path_1.feeling: Talky, tender, and prickly in a way that mostly works.

path_1.title: Joe's Apartment (1996)
path_1.feeling: Gross-out gimmickry that wears out its welcome fast.

path_1.title: Crime and Punishment in Suburbia (2000)
path_1.feeling: Dark teen melodrama with flashes of bite but an uneven tone.

path_1.title: Evil Dead, The (1981)
path_1.feeling: Inventive DIY terror and manic energy outweigh the rough edges.

path_1.title: S.O.B. (1981)
path_1.feeling: A caustic Hollywood send-up that’s sharp in places and slack in others.

path_2.title: French Kiss (1995)
path_2.feeling: Pleasant chemistry and travelogue charm, but too fluffy to really stick.

path_2.title: Bottle Rocket (1996)
path_2.feeling: Offbeat caper with shaggy charm and dry laughs that sneak up on me.

path_2.title: Jungle Book, The (1967)
path_2.feeling: Easygoing tunes and breezy vibe, enjoyable if slight for me.

path_2.title: Meet the Deedles (1998)
path_2.feeling: Loud, dopey gags with zero wit—my patience tapped out fast.

path_2.title: Good Morning, Vietnam (1987)
path_2.feeling: Williams’ manic humor and the bittersweet undercurrent make a sturdy, affecting mix.

path_2.title: Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil (1997)
path_2.feeling: Moody and meandering

path_2.title: Roger & Me (1989)
path_2.feeling: Pointed, scrappy, and funny enough, even if rough around the edges.

path_2.title: Phenomenon (1996)
path_2.feeling: High-concept heart-tugging that leans a bit too sugary for my taste.

path_2.title: Evil Dead, The (1981)
path_2.feeling: Inventive, splattery energy I admire more than I love.

path_2.title: Angel Heart (1987)
path_2.feeling: Sultry, occult noir that crawls under the skin and stays there.

path_2.title: Event Horizon (1997)
path_2.feeling: Grand guignol in space—some eerie imagery, but the pulp outweighs the payoff.

path_2.title: Vanishing, The (1993)
path_2.feeling: Creepy premise dulled by a misjudged tone and choices I couldn’t buy.

path_2.title: 2010: The Year We Make Contact (1984)
path_2.feeling: Competent, earnest, and disappointingly literal where I wanted mystery.

path_2.title: Airplane! (1980)
path_2.feeling: Relentless joke machine with deadpan precision—still hits like a sugar rush.

path_2.title: Mrs. Winterbourne (1996)
path_2.feeling: Sweet enough, but sitcom contrivances keep tripping the romance.

path_2.title: Dead Again (1991)
path_2.feeling: Glossy, twisty fun with a pulpy heartbeat and stylish flourishes.

path_2.title: Money Talks (1997)
path_2.feeling: High-volume antics with thin laughs and thinner characters.

path_2.title: Bob Roberts (1992)
path_2.feeling: Sharp, catchy political satire that skewers with a smile.

path_2.title: Mumford (1999)
path_2.feeling: Gentle small-town quirks that go down easy if not deep.

path_2.title: Innerspace (1987)
path_2.feeling: Goofy, brisk sci-fi romp with enough charm to carry the nonsense.

path_2.title: When Harry Met Sally... (1989)
path_2.feeling: Smart, warm banter and keen observations—comfort food done right.

path_2.title: Girl 6 (1996)
path_2.feeling: Interesting ideas and style, but the pieces don’t quite click.

path_2.title: Name of the Rose, The (Name der Rose, Der) (1986)
path_2.feeling: Process doc craft is neat, though it plays like an extra for fans only.

path_2.title: Clerks (1994)
path_2.feeling: Filthy, funny, and weirdly heartfelt—my sweet spot for slacker talk.

path_2.title: Mighty Ducks, The (1992)
path_2.feeling: Formulaic feel-good sports fare that’s serviceable if predictable.

path_2.title: Goodbye Girl, The (1977)
path_2.feeling: Snappy Neil Simon rhythms with enough heart to win me over.

path_2.title: Joe's Apartment (1996)
path_2.feeling: Gross-out gimmick stretched thin—hard pass on singing roaches.

path_2.title: Crime and Punishment in Suburbia (2000)
path_2.feeling: Stylized teen noir impulses that intrigue more than they satisfy.

path_2.title: Evil Dead, The (1981)
path_2.feeling: Same verdict: wild DIY spirit, limited resonance for me.

path_2.title: S.O.B. (1981)
path_2.feeling: Acerbic Hollywood send-up with bite, messy but amusingly mean.

path_2.title: French Kiss (1995)
path_2.feeling: Light, charming fluff with enough banter to keep me aboard.

path_2.title: Bottle Rocket (1996)
path_2.feeling: Shaggy, low-key charm and offbeat caper vibes I can happily amble with.

path_2.title: Jungle Book, The (1967)
path_2.feeling: Breezy tunes and mellow animal hangouts—pleasant, not profound.

path_2.title: Meet the Deedles (1998)
path_2.feeling: Gratingly dumb hijinks that test my tolerance for surfer-stupid.

path_2.title: Good Morning, Vietnam (1987)
path_2.feeling: Williams’ riffing plus sobering context makes a messy but engaging mix.

path_2.title: Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil (1997)
path_2.feeling: Atmosphere to spare, momentum not so much.

path_2.title: Roger & Me (1989)
path_2.feeling: Pointed, scrappy, and funny enough to make the outrage sting.

path_2.title: Phenomenon (1996)
path_2.feeling: Earnest and syrupy—high concept in service of heavy schmaltz.

path_2.title: Evil Dead, The (1981)
path_2.feeling: DIY ferocity and relentless dread—rough but thrillingly alive.

path_2.title: Angel Heart (1987)
path_2.feeling: Sultry, occult noir that seeps under the skin.

path_2.title: Event Horizon (1997)
path_2.feeling: Grand guignol in space—loud, lurid, and only sporadically eerie.

path_2.title: Vanishing, The (1993)
path_2.feeling: A blunt, glossy redo that drains the dread.

path_2.title: 2010: The Year We Make Contact (1984)
path_2.feeling: Competent, literal-minded follow-up that explains away the mystery.

path_2.title: Airplane! (1980)
path_2.feeling: Joke-density nirvana—deadpan absurdity done right.

path_2.title: Mrs. Winterbourne (1996)
path_2.feeling: Cushy contrivance that never finds much spark.

path_2.title: Dead Again (1991)
path_2.feeling: Lush, twisty romantic noir with enjoyable bravado.

path_2.title: Money Talks (1997)
path_2.feeling: Shrill, slapdash action-comedy with few real laughs.

path_2.title: Bob Roberts (1992)
path_2.feeling: Acerbic political mock-doc that hits plenty of bitter notes.

path_2.title: Mumford (1999)
path_2.feeling: Gentle small-town quirks that go down easy if a bit tidy.

path_2.title: Innerspace (1987)

path_2.title: When Harry Met Sally... (1989)
path_2.feeling: Smart, fizzy banter with real romantic ballast.

path_2.title: Girl 6 (1996)
path_2.feeling: Stylish and curious, but uneven in tone and bite.

path_2.title: Name of the Rose, The (Name der Rose, Der) (1986)

path_2.title: Clerks (1994)
path_2.feeling: Crudely sincere slackers talking themselves into my good graces.

path_2.title: Mighty Ducks, The (1992)

path_2.title: Evil Dead, The (1981)

path_2.title: S.O.B. (1981)
path_2.feeling: Caustic Hollywood send-up that’s sharp in spots, scattershot overall.

path_3.title: French Kiss (1995)
path_3.feeling: Cute travel-romp chemistry that’s pleasant if a bit too glossy and predictable for my taste.

path_3.title: Bottle Rocket (1996)
path_3.feeling: Low-key, offbeat crime shenanigans with endearingly odd rhythms—my kind of mellow clever.

path_3.title: Jungle Book, The (1967)
path_3.feeling: Breezy, tuneful comfort food, charming even if it doesn’t hit my sharper-comedy sweet spot.

path_3.title: Meet the Deedles (1998)
path_3.feeling: Grating, dopey hijinks with almost no wit—hard pass.

path_3.title: Good Morning, Vietnam (1987)
path_3.feeling: Energetic, character-first humor with an edge that mostly earns its sentiment.

path_3.title: Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil (1997)
path_3.feeling: Atmospheric and eccentric, but the languid sprawl dulls the mystery.

path_3.title: Roger & Me (1989)
path_3.feeling: Scrappy, sardonic doc that lands enough punches despite rough edges.

path_3.title: Phenomenon (1996)
path_3.feeling: High-concept schmaltz that leans more mawkish than meaningful.

path_3.title: Evil Dead, The (1981)
path_3.feeling: Raw, relentless cabin nightmare whose gonzo energy and practical mayhem win me over.

path_3.title: Angel Heart (1987)
path_3.feeling: Sultry, doom-soaked occult noir that gets under the skin.

path_3.title: Event Horizon (1997)
path_3.feeling: Moody haunted-ship vibes undercut by clunky, heavy-handed shocks.

path_3.title: Vanishing, The (1993)
path_3.feeling: The premise hooks me, but the execution flattens the dread I crave.

path_3.title: 2010: The Year We Make Contact (1984)
path_3.feeling: Competent space procedural that drains the mystery instead of deepening it.

path_3.title: Airplane! (1980)
path_3.feeling: Machine-gun gags and deadpan idiocy executed with precision—an all-timer.

path_3.title: Mrs. Winterbourne (1996)
path_3.feeling: Cinderella contrivances played broad and syrupy—not my tempo.

path_3.title: Dead Again (1991)
path_3.feeling: Glossy, twisty romance-thriller that’s playful enough to keep me engaged.

path_3.title: Money Talks (1997)
path_3.feeling: Loud, slick action-comedy with sporadic laughs and plenty of filler.

path_3.title: Bob Roberts (1992)
path_3.feeling: Sharp political satire that sings with darkly funny bite.

path_3.title: Mumford (1999)
path_3.feeling: Gentle, quirky small-town vibes—pleasant, if a little too tidy.

path_3.title: Innerspace (1987)
path_3.feeling: Amusing high-concept romp that’s fun more than truly clever.

path_3.title: When Harry Met Sally... (1989)
path_3.feeling: Talky, witty romance that earns its warmth without pandering.

path_3.title: Girl 6 (1996)
path_3.feeling: Intriguing idea with flashes of personality, but it never quite coheres.

path_3.title: Name of the Rose, The (Name der Rose, Der) (1986)
path_3.feeling: Behind-the-scenes curiosities that interest in pieces more than as a whole.

path_3.title: Clerks (1994)

path_3.title: Mighty Ducks, The (1992)

path_3.title: Goodbye Girl, The (1977)

path_3.title: Jungle Book, The (1967)

path_3.title: Meet the Deedles (1998)

path_3.title: Good Morning, Vietnam (1987)
path_3.feeling: Williams’ manic wit shines even as the drama turns syrupy.

path_3.feeling: Moody Southern Gothic that intrigues but meanders.

path_3.title: Phenomenon (1996)

path_3.title: Angel Heart (1987)
path_3.feeling: Sultry, occult noir whose atmosphere lingers.

path_3.title: Vanishing, The (1993)

path_3.feeling: Competent but unnecessary sequel that explains the magic away.

path_3.title: Mrs. Winterbourne (1996)

path_3.title: Money Talks (1997)

path_3.title: Bob Roberts (1992)
path_3.feeling: Sharp, cynical campaign satire that still stings.

path_3.title: Mumford (1999)

path_3.feeling: Zippy, likable body-ride caper with goofy charm.

path_3.title: Girl 6 (1996)
path_3.feeling: Intriguing concept, uneven follow-through.

path_3.title: Joe's Apartment (1996)
path_3.feeling: A one-joke gross-out that wears thin immediately.

path_3.title: Crime and Punishment in Suburbia (2000)
path_3.feeling: Stylized teen noir that never fully lands.

path_3.title: Evil Dead, The (1981)
path_3.feeling: Same feral, handmade splatter—more spirit than subtlety.

path_3.title: S.O.B. (1981)
path_3.feeling: Caustic Hollywood self-satire that’s hit-or-miss.

path_3.title: French Kiss (1995)
path_3.feeling: Light, pleasant romcom where Kline carries the thin caper fluff.

path_3.title: Bottle Rocket (1996)
path_3.feeling: Low-key, offbeat crime lark whose deadpan charm hits my sweet spot.

path_3.title: Jungle Book, The (1967)
path_3.feeling: Breezy songs and laid-back charm that are enjoyable but slight for me.

path_3.title: Meet the Deedles (1998)
path_3.feeling: Shrill, dopey hijinks that mistake noise for humor.

path_3.title: Good Morning, Vietnam (1987)
path_3.feeling: Williams’ manic riffing delights and the drama works despite the gloss.

path_3.title: Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil (1997)
path_3.feeling: Savannah atmosphere intrigues more than the meandering mystery.

path_3.title: Roger & Me (1989)
path_3.feeling: Scrappy, pointed pursuit that’s funny and blunt in equal measure.

path_3.title: Phenomenon (1996)
path_3.feeling: A sweet, soft-focus fable where sentiment smothers the sci-fi hook.

path_3.title: Evil Dead, The (1981)
path_3.feeling: Gonzo DIY splatter with manic energy that impresses more than it haunts.

path_3.title: Angel Heart (1987)
path_3.feeling: Sultry, occult noir whose dread and atmosphere linger.

path_3.title: Event Horizon (1997)
path_3.feeling: Great haunted-ship premise but the schlocky excess undercuts the mood.

path_3.title: Vanishing, The (1993)
path_3.feeling: A defanged remake that drains the original’s dread.

path_3.title: 2010: The Year We Make Contact (1984)
path_3.feeling: Competent but pedestrian, offering answers where I preferred mystery.

path_3.title: Airplane! (1980)
path_3.feeling: Rapid-fire parody that still lands every absurd gag for me.

path_3.title: Mrs. Winterbourne (1996)
path_3.feeling: Earnest, contrived mistaken-identity fluff that goes down easy and leaves little.

path_3.title: Dead Again (1991)
path_3.feeling: Stylish, pulpy reincarnation noir with fun craftsmanship that runs a bit overripe.

path_3.title: Money Talks (1997)
path_3.feeling: Loud, frantic buddy caper with thin laughs and thinner stakes.

path_3.title: Bob Roberts (1992)
path_3.feeling: Sharp, chilly political satire that feels uncomfortably plausible.

path_3.title: Mumford (1999)
path_3.feeling: Gentle, quirky small-town yarn that’s pleasant but a touch too neat.

path_3.title: Innerspace (1987)
path_3.feeling: Goofy high-concept romp with flashes of wit that’s fun if a bit loud and cartoonish.

path_3.title: When Harry Met Sally... (1989)
path_3.feeling: Conversational wit and earned warmth make it my kind of romantic comedy.

path_3.title: Girl 6 (1996)
path_3.feeling: An intriguing premise with stylish touches whose execution feels scattershot.

path_3.title: Name of the Rose, The (Name der Rose, Der) (1986)
path_3.feeling: Niche behind-the-scenes doc with interesting process glimpses that’s dry and insular.

path_3.title: Clerks (1994)
path_3.feeling: Bitter, hilarious slacker banter that’s cheap to look at and sharp to the bone.

path_3.title: Mighty Ducks, The (1992)
path_3.feeling: Formula underdog uplift that’s amiable and forgettable.

path_3.title: Goodbye Girl, The (1977)
path_3.feeling: Simon’s quips and endearing leads make for a warm, witty hang that’s a bit stagey.

path_3.title: Joe's Apartment (1996)
path_3.feeling: Smirking, gross-out novelty that confuses ick for humor.

path_3.title: Crime and Punishment in Suburbia (2000)
path_3.feeling: Stylized teen angst-noir with ambition but not enough insight or bite.

path_3.title: Evil Dead, The (1981)
path_3.feeling: Inventive, feral splatter-horror that’s energizing more than truly haunting.

path_3.title: S.O.B. (1981)
path_3.feeling: A caustic Hollywood self-roast with sharp jabs amid shaggy, dated chaos.

path_3.title: French Kiss (1995)
path_3.feeling: Light, touristy rom-com whose charm can’t quite cover the formula.

path_3.title: Bottle Rocket (1996)
path_3.feeling: Low-key, deadpan caper whose amiable oddballs and small stakes win me over.

path_3.title: Jungle Book, The (1967)
path_3.feeling: Swinging tunes and shaggy, episodic charm that’s pleasant more than gripping.

path_3.title: Meet the Deedles (1998)
path_3.feeling: Grating, low-effort hijinks that mistake noise for wit.

path_3.title: Good Morning, Vietnam (1987)
path_3.feeling: Williams’s rapid-fire patter and bureaucratic friction land, even if it softens the edges.

path_3.title: Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil (1997)
path_3.feeling: Atmosphere-rich Southern drift that intrigues more than it compels.

path_3.title: Roger & Me (1989)
path_3.feeling: Scrappy, pointed populist doc—funny and potent if a bit scattershot.

path_3.title: Phenomenon (1996)
path_3.feeling: High-concept schmaltz that dulls its own wonder.

path_3.title: Evil Dead, The (1981)
path_3.feeling: Inventive, relentless DIY horror whose wild energy outweighs the splatter excess.

path_3.title: Angel Heart (1987)
path_3.feeling: Sultry, doom-laced noir horror with mood to spare and a wicked sting.

path_3.title: Event Horizon (1997)
path_3.feeling: Grand guignol space dread—clumsy, but the atmosphere works.

path_3.title: Vanishing, The (1993)
path_3.feeling: Defanged remake that misunderstands what made the original terrifying.

path_3.title: 2010: The Year We Make Contact (1984)
path_3.feeling: Competent, literal-minded follow-up that explains away the mystery I’d rather feel.

path_3.title: Airplane! (1980)
path_3.feeling: Machine-gun gag classic that still demolishes me with precision silliness.

path_3.title: Mrs. Winterbourne (1996)
path_3.feeling: Glossy mistaken-identity romance that goes down easy and mostly evaporates.

path_3.feeling: Velvety, twist-happy noir melodrama—corny in spots but brisk and fun.

path_3.title: Money Talks (1997)

path_3.title: Bob Roberts (1992)
path_3.feeling: Cold-eyed political satire that plays disturbingly plausible—and bitterly funny.

path_3.title: Mumford (1999)
path_3.feeling: Gentle, quirky therapy fable that’s pleasant if a little pat.

path_3.title: Innerspace (1987)
path_3.feeling: Loopy high-concept romp—uneven, but the goofy energy carries it.

path_3.feeling: Talky, witty romance that earns its warmth without pandering.

path_3.title: Girl 6 (1996)
path_3.feeling: Stylish and uneven—provocations that don’t quite cohere.

path_3.title: Name of the Rose, The (Name der Rose, Der) (1986)

path_5.title: Dead Again (1991)
path_5.feeling: Glossy, twisty noir-romance—showy, but satisfyingly so.

path_5.title: Money Talks (1997)
path_5.feeling: Noisy buddy action-comedy with few laughs that stick.

path_5.title: Bob Roberts (1992)
path_5.feeling: Barbed political satire that lands more hits than misses.

path_5.title: Mumford (1999)
path_5.feeling: Quirky small-town therapy fable—amiable, a little thin.

path_5.title: Innerspace (1987)
path_5.feeling: Light, imaginative romp that’s fun without lingering.

path_5.title: When Harry Met Sally... (1989)
path_5.feeling: Smart, lived-in banter and romance that holds up for me.

path_5.title: Girl 6 (1996)
path_5.feeling: Stylish, uneven experiment—interesting ideas, spotty execution.

path_5.title: Name of the Rose, The (Name der Rose, Der) (1986)
path_5.feeling: Behind-the-scenes craft is neat, but the making-of format limits me.

path_5.title: Clerks (1994)
path_5.feeling: Deadpan, filthy-talk snapshot that still crackles with wit.

path_5.title: Mighty Ducks, The (1992)
path_5.feeling: Genial underdog formula—cute, predictable, fine.

path_5.title: Goodbye Girl, The (1977)
path_5.feeling: Wry, warm Neil Simon chemistry that mostly clicks.

path_5.title: Joe's Apartment (1996)
path_5.feeling: Gimmicky gross-out musical shtick that grated fast.

path_5.title: Crime and Punishment in Suburbia (2000)
path_5.feeling: Dark teen melodrama with flashes of bite, uneven overall.

path_5.title: Evil Dead, The (1981)
path_5.feeling: Inventive cabin-in-the-woods ferocity I respect more than love.

path_5.title: S.O.B. (1981)
path_5.feeling: Hollywood-skewering farce with bite, messy but amusing.

path_5.title: French Kiss (1995)
path_5.feeling: Pleasant travel-romcom chemistry, but the contrived caper beats are strictly by the numbers.

path_5.title: Bottle Rocket (1996)
path_5.feeling: Low-key, offbeat caper with shaggy charm that grows on me.

path_5.title: Jungle Book, The (1967)
path_5.feeling: Classic tunes and amiable adventure that plays easy if unsurprising.

path_5.title: Meet the Deedles (1998)
path_5.feeling: Loud, dopey hijinks that wore out their welcome almost immediately.

path_5.title: Good Morning, Vietnam (1987)
path_5.feeling: Williams' manic wit balanced by real bite—broad yet affecting.

path_5.title: Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil (1997)
path_5.feeling: Moody Southern intrigue I enjoyed more for atmosphere than payoff.

path_5.title: Roger & Me (1989)
path_5.feeling: Pointed, funny, and human—effective agitprop that still lands.

path_5.title: Phenomenon (1996)
path_5.feeling: Gentle, sentimental sci-fi fable that goes down a bit too syrupy for me.

path_5.title: Evil Dead, The (1981)
path_5.feeling: Inventive splattercraft I respect more for energy than I enjoy for gore.

path_5.title: Angel Heart (1987)
path_5.feeling: Sultry, unsettling noir-horror that really gets under my skin.

path_5.title: Event Horizon (1997)
path_5.feeling: Space-gothic nastiness with mood to spare but uneven thrills.

path_5.title: Vanishing, The (1993)
path_5.feeling: Solid premise dulled by a flatter, safer approach than I wanted.

path_5.title: 2010: The Year We Make Contact (1984)
path_5.feeling: Competent, talky sequel that lacks the awe or urgency I crave.

path_5.feeling: Joke-a-second spoof that hits far more than it misses for me.
